Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List:
I think the course raised very important issues and teaches students to be critical of research; I can confidently say that I am more critical of methodology and findings after being guided by Beth.

I will say that the course did seem a bit disorganized, and the student presentations were almost always rushed at the ends. I like the the idea of having certain last names being responsible for different portions of the readings. I think this should be a regular part of the discussion to ensure that all students participate. It also makes the weekly reading less daunting.
I liked the course a lot and thought it brought a new perspective to how I think about study designs and health equity

This course provided a great introduction to health disparities through an epidemiological lens.  It was very helpful to address disparities through different disease process/age-related conditions each week as a means to explore this content.
Student-led discussions were a great experience to do and organize, but sometimes the questions were too pointed and didn't lead to a general discussion about the readings and synthesizing the readings overall as they related to the larger topic.

Beth prepared great readings that got us thinking about both structural and biological factors that create health disparities. 

The powerpoints, however, didn't seem to be the main focus on the classes and were more of a formality. Maybe having a summary sheet circulated before the class with key theories and topics can serve as a primer for the readings and discussion. The beginning of class can be dedicated to reviwing the primer and jump straight into student discussions for the majority of the class.
Overall excellent - very engaging and knowledgeable.  She also was wonderful at appreciating different viewpoints throughout the course and linking them back to the content.

Good way to become aware of the biological bases of health disparities. I would recommend it if you're looking for a course with the potential to have deeper conversations because of it's small class size.
Excellent course on health disparities.  Greatly informed my ideas and research going forward.
